articles.headline: Judge Throws Out 2 Antitrust Cases Against Facebook
articles.snippet: The decisions were a major blow to attempts to rein in Big Tech. The judge said one of the complaints, from the Federal Trade Commission, lacked facts and gave the agency 30 days to refile it.
articles.abstract: The decisions were a major blow to attempts to rein in Big Tech. The judge said one of the complaints, from the Federal Trade Commission, lacked facts and gave the agency 30 days to refile it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a stunning setback to regulators’ efforts to break up Facebook, a federal judge on Monday threw out antitrust lawsuits brought against the company by the Federal Trade Commission and more than 40 states.

articles.headline: High Lumber Prices Add Urgency to a Decades-Old Trade Fight
articles.snippet: Forced to pay more for wood, home builders want the Biden administration to settle a long-running dispute over Canadian imports. It won’t be easy.
articles.abstract: Forced to pay more for wood, home builders want the Biden administration to settle a long-running dispute over Canadian imports. It won’t be easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A trade dispute over Canadian lumber that began when Ronald Reagan was president has become a political problem for President Biden, with home builders and members of Congress urging the administration to try to strike a deal that could help bring down the cost of critical building materials.

articles.headline: Rubble, Narrow Voids, Storms: The Dangerous Rescue Effort in Miami
articles.snippet: The death toll rose to 11 as search-and-rescue teams continued to sort through pulverized steel and dig through concrete boulders.
articles.abstract: The death toll rose to 11 as search-and-rescue teams continued to sort through pulverized steel and dig through concrete boulders.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Atop the grim pile of detritus and broken concrete on Monday, some of the world’s most elite rescue crews tunneled and dug, sometimes with their hands, in hopes of finding hints of the living. As the afternoon dragged on, it appeared their hopes would be dashed for another day.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Richard Fausset and Christina Morales

articles.headline: Boom Times for Lawyers as Washington Pursues Big Tech
articles.snippet: Not since the government sued to break up Microsoft in the late 1990s has there been greater demand for people who know the ins and outs of corporate competition law.
articles.abstract: Not since the government sued to break up Microsoft in the late 1990s has there been greater demand for people who know the ins and outs of corporate competition law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers at Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick, a top corporate law firm, were abuzz on Monday as they grappled with a federal judge’s rulings about antitrust cases related to their client: Facebook.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe

articles.headline: ‘A Form of Brainwashing’: China Remakes Hong Kong
articles.snippet: Neighbors are urged to report on one another. Children are taught to look for traitors. Officials are pressed to pledge their loyalty.
articles.abstract: Neighbors are urged to report on one another. Children are taught to look for traitors. Officials are pressed to pledge their loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With each passing day, the boundary between Hong Kong and the rest of China fades faster.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang, Alexandra Stevenson and Lam Yik Fei

articles.headline: Lower Rents? Check. Speakeasy? Check. How Office Landlords Are Enticing Tenants.
articles.snippet: As New York City stirs to life, landlords are trying to hold on to their tenants by redesigning spaces to accommodate social distancing and Zoom calls — but also socializing.
articles.abstract: As New York City stirs to life, landlords are trying to hold on to their tenants by redesigning spaces to accommodate social distancing and Zoom calls — but also socializing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as life returns to many New York City neighborhoods, its big commercial districts are awash with empty office space. Most workers haven’t yet returned — and it’s unclear if they all will. That uncertainty is terrifying the city’s biggest office landlords, and many of them are going to great lengths to retain and attract tenants.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: United Airlines Plans a Record Fleet Expansion as Travel Rebounds
articles.snippet: The carrier is ordering 270 single-aisle planes from Boeing and Airbus, signaling confidence that the pandemic is receding and travelers will spend on premium service.
articles.abstract: The carrier is ordering 270 single-aisle planes from Boeing and Airbus, signaling confidence that the pandemic is receding and travelers will spend on premium service.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines announced on Tuesday that it would place the largest order for airplanes in its history and create about 25,000 jobs a year after a pandemic devastated its business, betting on a domestic travel boom and demand for more expensive, premium seats.
